    <title data-rh="true">How West Virginia Became a U.S. Leader in Vaccine Rollout - The New York Times</title>
    <meta data-rh="true" property="article:published_time" content="2021-01-25T00:20:09.000Z"/><meta data-rh="true" property="article:modified_time" content="2021-01-28T15:20:23.000Z"/><meta data-rh="true" http-equiv="Content-Language" content="en"/><meta data-rh="true" name="robots" content="noarchive"/><meta data-rh="true" name="articleid" content="100000007564884"/><meta data-rh="true" name="nyt_uri" content="nyt://article/8ce3d503-a598-5d17-840e-6a0ceb1075a9"/><meta data-rh="true" name="pubp_event_id" content="pubp://event/efbd18dc0fa84aceb4aeefe1f81c6885"/><meta data-rh="true" name="description" content="West Virginia has used 83 percent of its allotted vaccines, among the best in the nation. But even efficient operations face a major problem: There simply are not enough shots to go around."/><meta data-rh="true" name="image" content="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2021/01/24/us/00virus-wvavaccine-lede-swap/00virus-wvavaccine-lede-swap-facebookJumbo-v2.jpg"/><meta data-rh="true" name="byl" content="By Sarah Mervosh"/><meta data-rh="true" name="thumbnail" content="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2021/01/24/us/00virus-wvavaccine-lede-swap/00virus-wvavaccine-lede-swap-thumbStandard-v2.jpg"/><meta data-rh="true" name="news_keywords" content="Vaccines Immunization,Coronavirus;COVID-19,Old age;elderly;senior citizens,West Virginia,US states,National Guard,Nursing home,Drugstore"/><meta data-rh="true" name="pdate" content="20210124"/><meta data-rh="true" property="og:url" content="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/24/us/west-virginia-vaccine.html"/><meta data-rh="true" property="og:type" content="article"/><meta data-rh="true" property="og:title" content="How West Virginia Became a U.S. Leader in Vaccine Rollout"/><meta data-rh="true" property="og:image" content="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2021/01/24/us/00virus-wvavaccine-lede-swap/00virus-wvavaccine-lede-swap-facebookJumbo-v2.jpg"/><meta data-rh="true" property="og:image:alt" content="A nurse held up a sign for her next vaccine recipient in a former department store in Morgantown, W.Va."/><meta data-rh="true" property="og:description" content="West Virginia has used 83 percent of its allotted vaccines, among the best in the nation.   (function initWebUnifiedTracking(root) {
  var _root;

  root = root || (typeof window !== 'undefined' ? window : undefined);
  var UnifiedTracking = ((_root = root) === null || _root === void 0 ? void 0 : _root.UnifiedTracking) || {};
  UnifiedTracking.context = 'web';

  if (!root) {
    return UnifiedTracking;
  }

  root.UnifiedTracking = UnifiedTracking;

  UnifiedTracking.sendAnalytic = function sendAnalytic(eventName, dataBlob) {
    root.dataLayer = root.dataLayer || [];

    if (Array.isArray(root.dataLayer)) {
      // Don't use a spread operator here for babel reasons
      dataBlob.event = dataBlob.event || eventName;
      root.dataLayer.push(dataBlob);
    }

    return Promise.resolve({
      success: true
    });
  };

  return UnifiedTracking;
})(window);

  if (typeof testCookie === 'undefined') {
    var testCookie = function (name) {
      var match = document.cookie.match(new RegExp(name + '=([^;]+)'));
      if (match) return match[1];
    }

</script><script data-rh="true" >if (window.NYTD && window.NYTD.Abra && window.NYTD.Abra('dfp_story_toggle') !== '1_block') {
    
  function placeGpt() {
    var purrCookie = testCookie('nyt-purr');
    if (purrCookie && purrCookie.substring(4, 5) === 's' ||
        purrCookie && purrCookie.substring(4, 5) === 'a'
    ) return;
    var gptScript = document.createElement('script');
    gptScript.async = 'async';
    gptScript.src = '//securepubads.g.doubleclick.net/tag/js/gpt.js';
    document.head.appendChild(gptScript);
  }
  placeGpt();

e1h9rw200" data-test-id="headline">How West Virginia Became a U.S. Leader in Vaccine Rollout</h1></div><p id="article-summary" class="css-w6ymp8 e1wiw3jv0">West Virginia has used 83 percent of its allotted vaccines, among the best in the nation. But even efficient operations face a major problem: There simply are not enough shots to go around.</p><div class="css-1aweabf"><div class="css-1oommtz"><div role="toolbar" aria-label="Social Media class="css-1xbhk30 email-share-item"><a href="mailto:?subject=NYTimes.com%3A%20How%20West%20Virginia%20Became%20a%20U.S.%20Leader%20in%20Vaccine%20Rollout&amp;body=From%20The%20New%20York%20Times%3A%0A%0AHow%20West%20Virginia%20Became%20a%20U.S.%20Leader%20in%20Vaccine%20Rollout%0A%0AWest%20Virginia%20has%20used%2083%20percent%20of%20its%20allotted%20vaccines%2C%20among%20the%20best%20in%20the%20nation.%20But%20even%20efficient%20operations%20face%20a%20major%20problem%3A%20There%20simply%20are%20not%20enough%20shots%20to%20go%20around.%0A%0Ahttps%3A%2F%2Fwww.nytimes.com%2F2021%2F01%2F24%2Fus%2Fwest-virginia-vaccine.html%3Fsmid%3Dem-share" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" aria-label="Email"><svg viewBox="0 0 15 9" class="css-1acmxgr" width="15" height="9"><path fill-rule="evenodd" clip-rule="evenodd" d="M.906 8.418V0L5.64 more-share-item"><div class="css-6n7j50"><button aria-haspopup="true" aria-expanded="false" aria-label="More sharing options ..." class="css-16ogagc" data-testid="" type="button"><svg class="css-107sgp6" viewBox="0 0 16 13" width="16" height="13"><path fill-rule="evenodd" clip-rule="evenodd" d="M15.406 5.359L8.978 0v3.215C3.82 3.215.406 8.107.406 12.66 1.653 9.133 4.29 7.517 8.978 7.517v3.2l6.428-5.358z" fill="#000"></path></svg></button></div></li><li class="css-1xbhk30"></li><li class="css-1hztko0"></li></ul></div></div></div><div class="css-79elbk" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper"><div class="css-z3e15g" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper-hidden"></div><div data-testid="photoviewer-children" class="css-1a48zt4 ehw59r15"><figure class="sizeLarge layoutHorizontal css-1ox9jel" aria-label="media" role="group"><div class="css-bsn42l"><picture><source media="(max-width: 599px) and (min-device-pixel-ratio: 3),(max-width: 599px) and (-webkit-min-device-pixel-ratio: 3),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 3dppx),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 288dpi)" srcSet="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2021/01/24/us/00virus-wvavaccine-lede-swap/00virus-wvavaccine-lede-swap-mobileMasterAt3x-v2.jpg?quality=75&amp;auto=webp&amp;disable=upscale&amp;width=600"/><source media="(max-width: 599px) and (min-device-pixel-ratio: 2),(max-width: 599px) and (-webkit-min-device-pixel-ratio: 2),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 2dppx),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 192dpi)" srcSet="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2021/01/24/us/00virus-wvavaccine-lede-swap/00virus-wvavaccine-lede-swap-mobileMasterAt3x-v2.jpg?quality=75&amp;auto=webp&amp;disable=upscale&amp;width=1200"/><source media="(max-width: 599px) and (min-device-pixel-ratio: 1),(max-width: 599px) and (-webkit-min-device-pixel-ratio: 1),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 1dppx),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 96dpi)" srcSet="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2021/01/24/us/00virus-wvavaccine-lede-swap/00virus-wvavaccine-lede-swap-mobileMasterAt3x-v2.jpg?quality=75&amp;auto=webp&amp;disable=upscale&amp;width=1800"/><img alt="A nurse held up a sign for her next vaccine recipient in a former department store in Morgantown, W.Va." class="css-11cwn6f" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2021/01/24/us/00virus-wvavaccine-lede-swap/00virus-wvavaccine-lede-swap-articleLarge-v2.jpg?quality=75&amp;auto=webp&amp;disable=upscale" srcSet="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2021/01/24/us/00virus-wvavaccine-lede-swap/00virus-wvavaccine-lede-swap-articleLarge-v2.jpg?quality=90&amp;auto=webp 600w,https://static01.nyt.com/images/2021/01/24/us/00virus-wvavaccine-lede-swap/00virus-wvavaccine-lede-swap-jumbo-v2.jpg?quality=90&amp;auto=webp 1024w,https://static01.nyt.com/images/2021/01/24/us/00virus-wvavaccine-lede-swap/00virus-wvavaccine-lede-swap-superJumbo-v2.jpg?quality=90&amp;auto=webp 2048w" sizes="((min-width: 600px) and (max-width: 1004px)) 84vw, (min-width: 1005px) 80vw, 100vw" decoding="async"/></picture></div><figcaption class="css-17ai7jg e18f7pbr0"><span aria-hidden="true" class="css-16f3y1r e13ogyst0">A nurse held up a sign for her next vaccine recipient in a former department store in Morgantown, W.Va.</span><span class="css-cnj6d5 e1z0qqy90"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Credit...</span><span><span>Kristian Thacker for The New York Times</span></span></span></figcaption></figure></div></div><div class="css-18e8msd"><div class="css-vp77d3 epjyd6m0"><div class="css-hus3qt ey68jwv0" aria-hidden="true"><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/sarah-mervosh" class="css-uwwqev"><img alt="Sarah Mervosh" title="Sarah Mervosh" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2018/07/18/multimedia/author-sarah-mervosh/author-sarah-mervosh-thumbLarge-v3.png" class="css-1rjmmt7 ey68jwv2"/></a></div><div class="css-1baulvz"><p class="css-4z5zii e1jsehar1"><span class="byline-prefix">By </span><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/sarah-mervosh" class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline">Sarah Mervosh</span></a></p></div></div><ul class="css-1u1psjv epjyd6m3"><li class="css-ccw2r3 epjyd6m1"><time dateTime="2021-01-28T10:20:23-05:00" class="css-ld3wwf e16638kd2"><span class="css-1sbuyqj e16638kd3">Published <!-- -->Jan. 24, 2021</span><span class="css-233int e16638kd4">Updated <!-- -->Jan. 28, 2021</span></time></li></ul></div></header><section name="articleBody" class="meteredContent css-1r7ky0e"><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">CHARLESTON, W.Va. — Carolyn Zain had heard horror stories about the nation’s coronavirus <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/28/world/europe/vaccine-secret-contracts-prices.html" title="">vaccine</a> rollout: long waits, clunky websites, people being turned away. So when her health department announced it was expanding appointments, she armed herself with two phones — cellphone in one hand, landline in the other — and held her breath.</p><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">Within 20 minutes, she secured a slot for the next day. She arrived for her 2 p.m. appointment and was resting in a chair, a fresh shot in her arm, by 2:21 p.m.</p><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">“It went wonderfully,” said Ms. Zain, 79, who, after a year spent mostly home alone, wore a sequined face mask that shimmered like confetti for her appointment at a Charleston clinic last week.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">Since the nation began distributing vaccines more than a month ago, it has moved far more slowly than officials hoped and has been stymied by <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/12/31/health/vaccine-distribution-delays.html" title="">widespread logistical problems</a>. But West Virginia has stood out for its success in getting people vaccinated. About 9 percent of all West Virginians have received a first dose of the coronavirus vaccine, a larger segment than in every state but Alaska and double the rate of some. No state has given a larger share of its residents second doses, a crucial step to securing the best chance at immunity.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">While many states are struggling to hand out the shots that the federal government has provided to them, West Virginia has given out <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/us/covid-19-vaccine-doses.html" title="">83 percent of its doses</a>, by far among the highest. The patchwork system of distribution in the country is in its early weeks, and experts say operations may change significantly as vaccinations gear up further, but many states so far have struggled to give even half of their allotted vaccines. California and Rhode Island have used just 45 percent of their shots.</p><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">“West Virginia is about at the top of the charts,” said Dr. Mark McClellan, a former commissioner of the U.S. Food and Drug Administration. “We need to get more states to the point that they have the vaccination capacity of West Virginia.”</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-79elbk" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper"><div class="css-z3e15g" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper-hidden"></div><div data-testid="photoviewer-children" class="css-1a48zt4 ehw59r15"><figure class="css-1ef8w8q e1g7ppur0" aria-label="media" role="group"><div class="css-1xdhyk6 erfvjey0"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Image</span><picture><source media="(max-width: 599px) and (min-device-pixel-ratio: 3),(max-width: 599px) and (-webkit-min-device-pixel-ratio: 3),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 3dppx),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 288dpi)" srcSet="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2021/01/24/us/00virus-wvavaccine-2-swap/merlin_182687484_4426d153-f686-4276-b66e-4082ce2c3ccb-mobileMasterAt3x.jpg?quality=75&amp;auto=webp&amp;disable=upscale&amp;width=600"/><source media="(max-width: 599px) and (min-device-pixel-ratio: 2),(max-width: 599px) and (-webkit-min-device-pixel-ratio: 2),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 2dppx),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 192dpi)" srcSet="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2021/01/24/us/00virus-wvavaccine-2-swap/merlin_182687484_4426d153-f686-4276-b66e-4082ce2c3ccb-mobileMasterAt3x.jpg?quality=75&amp;auto=webp&amp;disable=upscale&amp;width=1200"/><source media="(max-width: 599px) and (min-device-pixel-ratio: 1),(max-width: 599px) and (-webkit-min-device-pixel-ratio: 1),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 1dppx),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 96dpi)" srcSet="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2021/01/24/us/00virus-wvavaccine-2-swap/merlin_182687484_4426d153-f686-4276-b66e-4082ce2c3ccb-mobileMasterAt3x.jpg?quality=75&amp;auto=webp&amp;disable=upscale&amp;width=1800"/><img alt="Members of a vaccine task force met in West Virginia’s command center." class="css-1m50asq" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2021/01/24/us/00virus-wvavaccine-2-swap/merlin_182687484_4426d153-f686-4276-b66e-4082ce2c3ccb-articleLarge.jpg?quality=75&amp;auto=webp&amp;disable=upscale" srcSet="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2021/01/24/us/00virus-wvavaccine-2-swap/merlin_182687484_4426d153-f686-4276-b66e-4082ce2c3ccb-articleLarge.jpg?quality=90&amp;auto=webp 600w,https://static01.nyt.com/images/2021/01/24/us/00virus-wvavaccine-2-swap/merlin_182687484_4426d153-f686-4276-b66e-4082ce2c3ccb-jumbo.jpg?quality=90&amp;auto=webp 1024w,https://static01.nyt.com/images/2021/01/24/us/00virus-wvavaccine-2-swap/merlin_182687484_4426d153-f686-4276-b66e-4082ce2c3ccb-superJumbo.jpg?quality=90&amp;auto=webp 2048w" sizes="((min-width: 600px) and (max-width: 1004px)) 84vw, (min-width: 1005px) 80vw, 100vw" decoding="async"/></picture></div><figcaption class="css-18crmh6 ewdxa0s0"><span aria-hidden="true" class="css-16f3y1r e13ogyst0">Members of a vaccine task force met in West Virginia’s command center.</span><span class="css-cnj6d5 e1z0qqy90"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Credit...</span><span>Kristian Thacker for The New York Times</span></span></figcaption></figure></div></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">As many states struggle with <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/23/us/coronavirus-vaccines-canceled-appointments-shortages.html" title="">logistical and bureaucratic challenges</a>, leaving vaccines unused, West Virginia offers a remarkable example of a state that has successfully given out almost all of its shots. Yet it provides perhaps the clearest picture of a more fundamental problem that looms ahead for the country: Even the most efficient state vaccine operations do not have enough shots for all who want them.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">“It’s not like it’s a cake walk, but we have efficiency,” said Dr. Clay Marsh, the state coronavirus czar. He estimated that West Virginia has the capacity to handle 125,000 doses a week, but is getting just 23,600. At the current pace, officials said, it could take up to five months to finish vaccinating people 65 and older, let alone younger people in the general population.</p><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">“We can push a lot more,” Dr. Marsh said. “We just don’t have anything to push.”</p><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">The race to vaccinate millions of Americans comes as the country confronts <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/15/health/covid-cdc-variant.html" title="">worrying new variants of the virus</a>. The stakes are particularly high in West Virginia, where residents are among the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.prb.org/which-us-states-are-the-oldest/" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">oldest</a> and <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://assets.americashealthrankings.org/app/uploads/ahr_2019annualreport.pdf" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">least healthy</a> in the nation. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.census.gov/quickfacts/WV" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">Two in 10</a> West Virginians are 65 or older, and <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.kff.org/global-health-policy/issue-brief/how-many-adults-are-at-risk-of-serious-illness-if-infected-with-coronavirus/" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">nearly half of adults have a higher risk</a> of developing a serious case of Covid-19.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">“People are dying every day,” said Albert L. Wright Jr., the chief executive of WVU Medicine, the state’s largest health care provider, which <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.wvpublic.org/health-science/2021-01-20/first-mega-site-covid-19-vaccination-clinic-in-west-virginia-opens-in-morgantown" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">opened a mega-clinic</a> in Morgantown last week. “We just realized, the only way out of this is to vaccinate our way out.”</p><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">While the rollout in West Virginia has not been without its frustrations for the many residents who are desperate to receive the vaccine, the state’s approach offers insight into what has worked.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-79elbk" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper"><div class="css-z3e15g" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper-hidden"></div><div data-testid="photoviewer-children" class="css-1a48zt4 ehw59r15"><figure class="css-1ef8w8q e1g7ppur0" aria-label="media" role="group"><div class="css-1xdhyk6 erfvjey0"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Image</span><div class="css-zjzyr8"><div data-testid="lazyimage-container" style="height:257.77777777777777px"></div></div></div><figcaption class="css-18crmh6 ewdxa0s0"><span aria-hidden="true" class="css-16f3y1r e13ogyst0">Jake Carr gave a vaccine to Carolyn Zain in Charleston on Thursday. </span><span class="css-cnj6d5 e1z0qqy90"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Credit...</span><span>Kristian Thacker for The New York Times</span></span></figcaption></figure></div></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">Early on, the state got a significant head start because it initially opted out of a federal program to vaccinate people in nursing homes and other long-term care facilities.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">While other states chose the federal plan, which partnered with Walgreens and CVS to inoculate people in nursing homes around the country, officials decided the idea made little sense in West Virginia, where many communities are tucked into the hills, miles from the nearest big box store, and about half of pharmacies are independently owned.</p><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">West Virginia created a network of pharmacies in the state, pairing them with about 200 long-term care facilities. As a result, West Virginia finished its first round of vaccinations at nursing homes last month, while many states were just getting started. By the end of this week, officials expect to have delivered a second round of shots to all nursing homes.</p><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">A growing number of governors and state health officials have <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/16/business/covid-vaccine-nursing-homes.html" title="">voiced frustration with the speed of the federal program</a>, which has been slow in part because of the sheer number of long-term care facilities nationwide. Some states, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://abcnews.go.com/Health/maine-shifts-vaccine-doses-cvs-walgreens/story?id=75401865" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">like Maine</a>, have also begun looking to local pharmacies as a resource.</p><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">“Using your local partners and really having more control over where the vaccine is going, that’s what has been successful for West Virginia,” said Claire Hannan, executive director of the Association of Immunization Managers.</p><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">The approach in some ways reflects the scrappy outlook that has become embedded in West Virginia, a state that is used to being labeled in broad strokes by outsiders. After years of coming in at the bottom of various national rankings — <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.cdc.gov/statesystem/cigaretteuseadult.html" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">highest rate of cigarette smokers</a>, largest share of adults with <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.americashealthrankings.org/explore/annual/measure/Smoking/state/WV" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">multiple chronic conditions</a>, among the highest prevalence of <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://dhhr.wv.gov/hpcd/data_reports/Pages/Fast-Facts.aspx" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">diabetes and obesity</a> — there is a sense of proud defiance around the state’s vaccine plan.</p><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">“Our state motto is montani semper liberi — mountaineers are always free,” said Stephen New, a lawyer in Beckley, whose father, a former coal miner, is scheduled to get vaccinated at a local clinic this week. “There is a fierce sense of independence here that we don’t need to follow others.”</p><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">Central to West Virginia’s strategy, too, is putting the National Guard at the helm of vaccine operations.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-79elbk" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper"><div class="css-z3e15g" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper-hidden"></div><div data-testid="photoviewer-children" class="css-1a48zt4 ehw59r15"><figure class="css-1ef8w8q e1g7ppur0" aria-label="media" role="group"><div class="css-1xdhyk6 erfvjey0"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Image</span><div class="css-zjzyr8"><div data-testid="lazyimage-container" style="height:257.77777777777777px"></div></div></div><figcaption class="css-18crmh6 ewdxa0s0"><span aria-hidden="true" class="css-16f3y1r e13ogyst0">Members of a state task force gather daily at a command center, not far from the state’s Capitol.</span><span class="css-cnj6d5 e1z0qqy90"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Credit...</span><span>Kristian Thacker for The New York Times</span></span></figcaption></figure></div></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">“They are logistical experts,” said Jim Kranz, a vice president at the West Virginia Hospital Association, who described a military approach far different than typical government bureaucracies jammed up by memos and lengthy meetings. “The Guard just says, ‘I don’t need a written plan, this is what we’re doing.’”</p><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">In recent weeks, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/14/us/politics/coronavirus-vaccine-national-guard.html" title="">other states have increasingly been turning to the National Guard</a> for assistance.</p><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">Inside a former drill hall on the National Guard’s gated campus in Charleston, a core state team of representatives from various agencies meets at a command center, working amid a labyrinth of computer screens, white boards and plexiglass dividers, in the shadow of an enormous American flag.</p><div id="NYT_MAIN_CONTENT_3_REGION" class="css-9tf9ac"><section id="styln-prism-freeform-1606244777627" class="interactive-content interactive-size-scoop css-retkgj"><div class="css-17ih8de interactive-body"><style>.css-c7gg1r{font-family:nyt-franklin,helvetica,arial,sans-serif;font-weight:700;font-size:0.875rem;line-height:0.875rem;margin-bottom:15px;color:#121212 !important;}@media (min-width:740px){.css-c7gg1r{font-size:0.9375rem;line-height:0.9375rem;}}.css-1sjr751{-webkit-text-decoration:none;text-decoration:none;}.css-1sjr751 a:hover{border-bottom:1px solid #dcdcdc;}.css-yoay6m{margin:0 auto 5px;font-family:nyt-franklin,helvetica,arial,sans-serif;font-weight:700;font-size:1.125rem;line-height:1.3125rem;color:#121212;}@media (min-width:740px){.css-yoay6m{font-size:1.25rem;line-height:1.4375rem;}}.css-1dg6kl4{margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:15px;}.css-k59gj9{display:-webkit-box;display:-webkit-flex;display:-ms-flexbox;display:flex;-webkit-flex-direction:column;-ms-flex-direction:column;flex-direction:column;width:100%;}.css-1e2usoh{font-family:inherit;display:-webkit-box;display:-webkit-flex;display:-ms-flexbox;display:flex;-webkit-box-pack:justify;-webkit-justify-content:space-between;-ms-flex-pack:justify;justify-content:space-between;border-top:1px solid #ccc;padding:10px 0px 10px 0px;background-color:#fff;}.css-1jz6h6z{font-family:inherit;font-weight:bold;font-size:1rem;line-height:1.5rem;text-align:left;}.css-1t412wb{box-sizing:border-box;margin:8px 15px 0px 15px;cursor:pointer;}.css-hhzar2{-webkit-transition:-webkit-transform ease 0.5s;-webkit-transition:transform ease 0.5s;transition:transform ease 0.5s;}.css-t54hv4{-webkit-transform:rotate(180deg);-ms-transform:rotate(180deg);transform:rotate(180deg);}.css-1r2j9qz{-webkit-transform:rotate(0deg);-ms-transform:rotate(0deg);transform:rotate(0deg);}.css-e1ipqs{font-size:1rem;line-height:1.5rem;padding:0px 30px 0px 0px;}.css-e1ipqs a{color:#326891;-webkit-text-decoration:underline;text-decoration:underline;}.css-e1ipqs a:hover{-webkit-text-decoration:none;text-decoration:none;}.css-1o76pdf{visibility:show;height:100%;padding-bottom:20px;}.css-1sw9s96{visibility:hidden;height:0px;}#masthead-bar-one{display:none;}#masthead-bar-one{display:none;}.css-1psxyob{background-color:white;border:1px solid #e2e2e2;width:calc(100% - 40px);max-width:600px;margin:1.5rem auto 1.9rem;padding:15px;box-sizing:border-box;font-family:'nyt-franklin',arial,helvetica,sans-serif;text-align:left;}@media (min-width:740px){.css-1psxyob{padding:20px;width:100%;}}.css-1psxyob:focus{outline:1px solid #e2e2e2;}</style><div class="css-1psxyob"><header class="css-1dg6kl4"><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/spotlight/coronavirus-vaccine" class="css-1sjr751"><h3 class="css-c7gg1r">Covid-19 Vaccines ›</h3></a><h4 class="css-yoay6m">Answers to Your Vaccine Questions</h4></header><div><div class="css-k59gj9"><button type="button" id="faq-question-0" class="css-1e2usoh"><span class="css-1jz6h6z">Am I eligible for the Covid vaccine in my state?</span><div role="button" class="css-1t412wb"><div class="css-hhzar2 css-t54hv4 faqCaret0"><svg width="12px" height="6px" viewBox="0 0 12 6" version="1.1" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><g stroke="none" stroke-width="1" fill="none" fill-rule="evenodd"><g transform="translate(-566.000000, -618.000000)" stroke="#979797"><polyline id="Path-2" points="567 618 572.230938 623.230938 577.381644 618.080232"></polyline></g></g></svg></div></div></button><div class="css-e1ipqs css-1o76pdf faqAnswer0"><p>Currently more than 150 million people — almost half the population — are eligible to be vaccinated. But <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/us/covid-19-vaccine-doses.html?name=styln-coronavirus-vaccines&region=TOP_BANNER█=storyline_menu_recirc&action=click&pgtype=Interactive&impression_id=262176c0-6174-11eb-9bbe-43be4a0f7ee0&variant=1_Show">each state makes the final decision about who goes first.</a> The nation’s 21 million health care workers and three million residents of long-term care facilities were the first to qualify. In mid-January, federal officials urged all states <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/12/us/politics/vaccine-states.html">to open up eligibility</a> to everyone 65 and older and to adults of any age with medical conditions that put them at high risk of becoming seriously ill or dying from Covid-19. <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/12/03/opinion/covid-19-vaccine-timeline.html">Adults in the general population are at the back of the line.</a> If federal and state health officials can clear up bottlenecks in vaccine distribution, everyone 16 and older will become eligible as early as this spring or early summer. The vaccine hasn’t been approved in children, although studies are underway. It may be months before a vaccine is available for anyone under the age of 16. <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/15/us/coronavirus-vaccine-states.html">Go to your state health website</a> for up-to-date information on vaccination policies in your area</p></div></div><div class="css-k59gj9"><button type="button" id="faq-question-1" class="css-1e2usoh"><span class="css-1jz6h6z">Is the vaccine free?</span><div role="button" class="css-1t412wb"><div class="css-hhzar2 css-1r2j9qz faqCaret1"><svg width="12px" height="6px" viewBox="0 0 12 6" version="1.1" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><g stroke="none" stroke-width="1" fill="none" fill-rule="evenodd"><g transform="translate(-566.000000, -618.000000)" stroke="#979797"><polyline id="Path-2" points="567 618 572.230938 623.230938 577.381644 618.080232"></polyline></g></g></svg></div></div></button><div class="css-e1ipqs css-1sw9s96 faqAnswer1"><p><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/12/17/upshot/vaccines-surprise-bills.html">You should not have to pay anything out of pocket to get the vaccine,</a> although you will be asked for insurance information. If you don’t have insurance, you should still be given the vaccine at no charge. Congress passed legislation this spring that bars insurers from applying any cost sharing, such as a co-payment or deductible. It layered on additional protections barring pharmacies, doctors and hospitals from billing patients, including those who are uninsured. Even so, health experts do worry that patients might stumble into loopholes that <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/12/17/upshot/vaccines-surprise-bills.html">leave them vulnerable to surprise bills.</a> This could happen to those who are charged a doctor visit fee along with their vaccine, or Americans who have certain types of health coverage that do not fall under the new rules. If you get your vaccine from a doctor’s office or urgent care clinic, talk to them about potential hidden charges. To be sure you won’t get a surprise bill, the best bet is to get your vaccine at a health department vaccination site or a local pharmacy once the shots become more widely available.</p></div></div><div class="css-k59gj9"><button type="button" id="faq-question-2" class="css-1e2usoh"><span class="css-1jz6h6z">Can I choose which vaccine I get?</span><div role="button" class="css-1t412wb"><div class="css-hhzar2 css-1r2j9qz faqCaret2"><svg width="12px" height="6px" viewBox="0 0 12 6" version="1.1" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><g stroke="none" stroke-width="1" fill="none" fill-rule="evenodd"><g transform="translate(-566.000000, -618.000000)" stroke="#979797"><polyline id="Path-2" points="567 618 572.230938 623.230938 577.381644 618.080232"></polyline></g></g></svg></div></div></button><div class="css-e1ipqs css-1sw9s96 faqAnswer2"><p>Probably not. The answer depends on a number of factors, including the supply in your area at the time you’re vaccinated. Check your state health department website for more information about the vaccines available in your state. <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/science/coronavirus-vaccine-tracker.html">The Pfizer and Moderna vaccines are the only two vaccines currently approved,</a> although a third vaccine from Johnson & Johnson is on the way.</p></div></div><div class="css-k59gj9"><button type="button" id="faq-question-3" class="css-1e2usoh"><span class="css-1jz6h6z">How long will the vaccine last? Will I need another one next year?</span><div role="button" class="css-1t412wb"><div class="css-hhzar2 css-1r2j9qz faqCaret3"><svg width="12px" height="6px" viewBox="0 0 12 6" version="1.1" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><g stroke="none" stroke-width="1" fill="none" fill-rule="evenodd"><g transform="translate(-566.000000, -618.000000)" stroke="#979797"><polyline id="Path-2" points="567 618 572.230938 623.230938 577.381644 618.080232"></polyline></g></g></svg></div></div></button><div class="css-e1ipqs css-1sw9s96 faqAnswer3"><p>That is to be determined. It’s possible that Covid-19 vaccinations will become an annual event, just like the flu shot. <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/11/17/health/coronavirus-immunity.html">Or it may be that the benefits of the vaccine last longer than a year.</a> We have to wait to see how durable the protection from the vaccines is. To determine this, researchers are going to be tracking vaccinated people to look for “breakthrough cases” — those people who get sick with Covid-19 despite vaccination. That is a sign of weakening protection and will give researchers clues about how long the vaccine lasts. They will also be monitoring levels of antibodies and T cells in the blood of vaccinated people to determine whether and when a booster shot might be needed. It’s conceivable that people may need boosters every few months, once a year or only every few years. It’s just a matter of waiting for the data.</p></div></div><div class="css-k59gj9"><button type="button" id="faq-question-4" class="css-1e2usoh"><span class="css-1jz6h6z">Will my employer require vaccinations?</span><div role="button" class="css-1t412wb"><div class="css-hhzar2 css-1r2j9qz faqCaret4"><svg width="12px" height="6px" viewBox="0 0 12 6" version="1.1" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><g stroke="none" stroke-width="1" fill="none" fill-rule="evenodd"><g transform="translate(-566.000000, -618.000000)" stroke="#979797"><polyline id="Path-2" points="567 618 572.230938 623.230938 577.381644 618.080232"></polyline></g></g></svg></div></div></button><div class="css-e1ipqs css-1sw9s96 faqAnswer4"><p><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/12/18/us/eeoc-employers-coronavirus-mandate.html">Employers do have the right to compel their workers to be vaccinated once a vaccine is formally approved.</a> Many hospital systems, for example, require annual flu shots. But employees can seek exemptions based on medical reasons or religious beliefs. In such cases, employers are supposed to provide a “reasonable accommodation” — with a coronavirus vaccine, for example, a worker might be allowed to work if they wear a mask, or to work from home.</p></div></div><div class="css-k59gj9"><button type="button" id="faq-question-5" class="css-1e2usoh"><span class="css-1jz6h6z">Where can I find out more?</span><div role="button" class="css-1t412wb"><div class="css-hhzar2 css-1r2j9qz faqCaret5"><svg width="12px" height="6px" viewBox="0 0 12 6" version="1.1" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><g stroke="none" stroke-width="1" fill="none" fill-rule="evenodd"><g transform="translate(-566.000000, -618.000000)" stroke="#979797"><polyline id="Path-2" points="567 618 572.230938 623.230938 577.381644 618.080232"></polyline></g></g></svg></div></div></button><div class="css-e1ipqs css-1sw9s96 faqAnswer5"><p>If you have other questions about the coronavirus vaccine, <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2021/well/covid-vaccine-questions.html">please read our full F.A.Q.</a></p></div></div></div><script>"use strict";var buttonsObj=document.getElementsByClassName("css-1e2usoh"),buttons=Object.values(buttonsObj);buttons.forEach(function(a,b){a.addEventListener("click",function(){var a=document.getElementsByClassName("faqAnswer"+b),c=document.getElementsByClassName("faqCaret"+b);a.length&&(a[0].classList.contains("css-1o76pdf")?(a[0].classList.replace("css-1o76pdf","css-1sw9s96"),c[0].classList.replace("css-t54hv4","css-1r2j9qz")):(a[0].classList.replace("css-1sw9s96","css-1o76pdf"),c[0].classList.replace("css-1r2j9qz","css-t54hv4")))})});//STYLN_feedback_form
var parent_domain=window.location.href,message={id:"styln-survey-component-faq-undefined",componentName:"faq",componentQuestion:"Was this F.A.Q. helpful?",storylineName:"undefined",formatName:"F.A.Q."};parent.postMessage(message,parent_domain);</script><div class="styln-survey-component" id="styln-survey-component-faq-coronavirus"></div></div></div></section></div><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">Officials in West Virginia say the in-person command center, which runs counter to pandemic-era Zoom meetings and may come with health risks, has also helped quickly resolve problems. For instance, a recent brainstorming meeting led to a swift change: To avoid a mix-up between Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccines, officials changed the colors of cards showing that a resident had been vaccinated — red for Moderna, blue for Pfizer.</p><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">“It’s a person at a table,” said Joe Peal, a retired colonel and the chief of staff for the vaccine task force. “We absolutely could not do it virtually.”</p><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">Officials say they have also learned what not to do — including not promising shots that they don’t yet have.</p><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">After a crowd of people in their 80s unexpectedly showed up outside the health department in Charleston one shivering winter night, officials there decided clinics could not be first-come, first-served. They required appointments, and to avoid later rescinding those appointments, as has happened in states like <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.ny1.com/nyc/all-boroughs/news/2021/01/20/vaccine-appointments-cancelled-in-new-york-city" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">New York</a> and <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.local10.com/news/local/2021/01/21/mount-sinai-cancels-first-dose-covid-19-vaccine-appointments-due-to-uncertainty-of-supply/" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">Florida</a>, appointments are not made until the county officials have that week’s allotment of vaccines on hand, sitting in their own freezer.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-79elbk" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper"><div class="css-z3e15g" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper-hidden"></div><div data-testid="photoviewer-children" class="css-1a48zt4 ehw59r15"><figure class="css-1ef8w8q e1g7ppur0" aria-label="media" role="group"><div class="css-1xdhyk6 erfvjey0"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Image</span><div class="css-zjzyr8"><div data-testid="lazyimage-container" style="height:257.77777777777777px"></div></div></div><figcaption class="css-18crmh6 ewdxa0s0"><span aria-hidden="true" class="css-16f3y1r e13ogyst0">Residents waited to receive vaccines in Charleston.</span><span class="css-cnj6d5 e1z0qqy90"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Credit...</span><span>Kristian Thacker for The New York Times</span></span></figcaption></figure></div></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">Some of West Virginia’s success also may partly be explained by characteristics of the state. Its population, 1.8 million people, is tiny compared to states like Texas, which are handling <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/us/covid-19-vaccine-doses.html" title="">far more vaccines</a>. West Virginia is also among only a handful of states that do not allow philosophical exemptions for vaccines for school, according to the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.immunize.org/" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">Immunization Action Coalition</a>, suggesting a culture where acceptance of vaccines may be more prevalent. </p><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">West Virginia’s rollout has by no means been without hiccups. And some of the problems have been similar to those in states with far worse records in distributing shots: Phone lines have been mobbed and many West Virginians have spent hours calling to get appointments without success.</p><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">The health department in Kanawha County, which includes Charleston, was so overloaded with phone calls last week, its phone system crashed and its Facebook page was flooded with complaints. “I’ve called 250+ times but still unable to get through,” one person wrote.</p><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">The distribution of vaccines — mainly to health care workers and older residents so far — also has been concentrated in urban centers, raising concerns about equal access in rural and more impoverished areas. Of the state’s 10 poorest counties, just one had a vaccine clinic in recent weeks, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://mountainstatespotlight.org/2021/01/21/in-west-virginias-poorest-communities-the-states-vaccine-rollout-has-left-vulnerable-residents-behind/" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">according to an analysis by the nonprofit newsroom Mountain State Spotlight</a>. </p><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">But the main problem, officials say, is not logistical but a matter of supply: They need more vaccine.</p><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">Dr. Sherri Young, the health officer in Kanawha County, said one big reason phone lines are overrun is because the county cannot reliably schedule clinics weeks in advance. If there were more vaccine, she said, “people wouldn’t be as panicked.”</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">Pfizer and Moderna have pledged to deliver a combined 200 million doses for use in the United States by the end of March, with an additional 200 million doses to be delivered by the end of July. A third vaccine maker, Johnson &amp; Johnson, could put millions more doses on the market if approved.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-79elbk" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper"><div class="css-z3e15g" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper-hidden"></div><div data-testid="photoviewer-children" class="css-1a48zt4 ehw59r15"><figure class="css-1ef8w8q e1g7ppur0" aria-label="media" role="group"><div class="css-1xdhyk6 erfvjey0"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Image</span><div class="css-zjzyr8"><div data-testid="lazyimage-container" style="height:257.77777777777777px"></div></div></div><figcaption class="css-18crmh6 ewdxa0s0"><span aria-hidden="true" class="css-16f3y1r e13ogyst0">Signs directed people to a vaccination clinic at the Charleston Coliseum and Convention Center.</span><span class="css-cnj6d5 e1z0qqy90"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Credit...</span><span>Kristian Thacker for The New York Times</span></span></figcaption></figure></div></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">West Virginia had hoped to make the case that because it is moving through its vaccines, it deserved to get more, but so far states have been allocated doses based on population.</p><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">Jim Doria, 69, a retired epidemiologist, had gone months without seeing his grandchildren who live in Philadelphia and was eager to be among the first to get vaccinated after the state opened the system to people in his age group last week. He estimated that he called as many as 700 times.</p><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">“I won the lottery,” he said, after getting off a wait list.</p><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">But for every person like Mr. Doria, countless others were left disappointed. Statewide, West Virginia has given shots to around 70,000 of its senior citizens, with more than 250,000 left to go.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div></section><div></div><div></div><div></div><div></div><div><div id="bottom-wrapper" class="css-1ede5it"><div id="bottom-slug" class="css-l9onyx"><p>Advertisement</p></div><a href="#after-bottom" style="position:absolute;width:1px;height:1px;margin:-1px;padding:0;border:0;clip:rect(0 0 0 0);overflow:hidden">Continue reading the main story</a><div class="ad bottom-wrapper" id="bottom" style="text-align:center;height:100%;display:block;min-height:90px"></div><div (min-width:740px){.css-1psxyob{padding:20px;width:100%;}}.css-1psxyob:focus{outline:1px solid #e2e2e2;}\u003C\u002Fstyle\u003E\u003Cdiv class=\"css-1psxyob\"\u003E\u003Cheader class=\"css-1dg6kl4\"\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002Fspotlight\u002Fcoronavirus-vaccine\" class=\"css-1sjr751\"\u003E\u003Ch3 class=\"css-c7gg1r\"\u003ECovid-19 Vaccines ›\u003C\u002Fh3\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Ch4 class=\"css-yoay6m\"\u003EAnswers to Your Vaccine Questions\u003C\u002Fh4\u003E\u003C\u002Fheader\u003E\u003Cdiv\u003E\u003Cdiv class=\"css-k59gj9\"\u003E\u003Cbutton type=\"button\" id=\"faq-question-0\" class=\"css-1e2usoh\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"css-1jz6h6z\"\u003EAm I eligible for the Covid vaccine in my state?\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cdiv role=\"button\" class=\"css-1t412wb\"\u003E\u003Cdiv class=\"css-hhzar2 css-t54hv4 faqCaret0\"\u003E\u003Csvg width=\"12px\" height=\"6px\" viewBox=\"0 0 12 6\" version=\"1.1\" xmlns=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.w3.org\u002F2000\u002Fsvg\" xmlns:xlink=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.w3.org\u002F1999\u002Fxlink\"\u003E\u003Cg stroke=\"none\" stroke-width=\"1\" fill=\"none\" fill-rule=\"evenodd\"\u003E\u003Cg transform=\"translate(-566.000000, -618.000000)\" stroke=\"#979797\"\u003E\u003Cpolyline id=\"Path-2\" points=\"567 618 572.230938 623.230938 577.381644 618.080232\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fpolyline\u003E\u003C\u002Fg\u003E\u003C\u002Fg\u003E\u003C\u002Fsvg\u003E\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\u003C\u002Fbutton\u003E\u003Cdiv class=\"css-e1ipqs css-1o76pdf faqAnswer0\"\u003E\u003Cp\u003ECurrently more than 150 million people — almost half the population — are eligible to be vaccinated. But \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002Finteractive\u002F2020\u002Fus\u002Fcovid-19-vaccine-doses.html?name=styln-coronavirus-vaccines&region=TOP_BANNER█=storyline_menu_recirc&action=click&pgtype=Interactive&impression_id=262176c0-6174-11eb-9bbe-43be4a0f7ee0&variant=1_Show\"\u003Eeach state makes the final decision about who goes first.\u003C\u002Fa\u003E The nation’s 21 million health care workers and three million residents of long-term care facilities were the first to qualify. In mid-January, federal officials urged all states \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2021\u002F01\u002F12\u002Fus\u002Fpolitics\u002Fvaccine-states.html\"\u003Eto open up eligibility\u003C\u002Fa\u003E to everyone 65 and older and to adults of any age with medical conditions that put them at high risk of becoming seriously ill or dying from Covid-19. \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002Finteractive\u002F2020\u002F12\u002F03\u002Fopinion\u002Fcovid-19-vaccine-timeline.html\"\u003EAdults in the general population are at the back of the line.\u003C\u002Fa\u003E If federal and state health officials can clear up bottlenecks in vaccine distribution, everyone 16 and older will become eligible as early as this spring or early summer. The vaccine hasn’t been approved in children, although studies are underway. It may be months before a vaccine is available for anyone under the age of 16. \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2021\u002F01\u002F15\u002Fus\u002Fcoronavirus-vaccine-states.html\"\u003EGo to your state health website\u003C\u002Fa\u003E for up-to-date information on vaccination policies in your area\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\u003Cdiv class=\"css-k59gj9\"\u003E\u003Cbutton type=\"button\" id=\"faq-question-1\" class=\"css-1e2usoh\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"css-1jz6h6z\"\u003EIs the vaccine free?\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cdiv role=\"button\" class=\"css-1t412wb\"\u003E\u003Cdiv class=\"css-hhzar2 css-1r2j9qz faqCaret1\"\u003E\u003Csvg width=\"12px\" height=\"6px\" viewBox=\"0 0 12 6\" version=\"1.1\" xmlns=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.w3.org\u002F2000\u002Fsvg\" xmlns:xlink=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.w3.org\u002F1999\u002Fxlink\"\u003E\u003Cg stroke=\"none\" stroke-width=\"1\" fill=\"none\" fill-rule=\"evenodd\"\u003E\u003Cg transform=\"translate(-566.000000, -618.000000)\" stroke=\"#979797\"\u003E\u003Cpolyline id=\"Path-2\" points=\"567 618 572.230938 623.230938 577.381644 618.080232\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fpolyline\u003E\u003C\u002Fg\u003E\u003C\u002Fg\u003E\u003C\u002Fsvg\u003E\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\u003C\u002Fbutton\u003E\u003Cdiv class=\"css-e1ipqs css-1sw9s96 faqAnswer1\"\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2020\u002F12\u002F17\u002Fupshot\u002Fvaccines-surprise-bills.html\"\u003EYou should not have to pay anything out of pocket to get the vaccine,\u003C\u002Fa\u003E although you will be asked for insurance information. If you don’t have insurance, you should still be given the vaccine at no charge. Congress passed legislation this spring that bars insurers from applying any cost sharing, such as a co-payment or deductible. It layered on additional protections barring pharmacies, doctors and hospitals from billing patients, including those who are uninsured. Even so, health experts do worry that patients might stumble into loopholes that \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2020\u002F12\u002F17\u002Fupshot\u002Fvaccines-surprise-bills.html\"\u003Eleave them vulnerable to surprise bills.\u003C\u002Fa\u003E This could happen to those who are charged a doctor visit fee along with their vaccine, or Americans who have certain types of health coverage that do not fall under the new rules. If you get your vaccine from a doctor’s office or urgent care clinic, talk to them about potential hidden charges. To be sure you won’t get a surprise bill, the best bet is to get your vaccine at a health department vaccination site or a local pharmacy once the shots become more widely available.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\u003Cdiv class=\"css-k59gj9\"\u003E\u003Cbutton type=\"button\" id=\"faq-question-2\" class=\"css-1e2usoh\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"css-1jz6h6z\"\u003ECan I choose which vaccine I get?\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cdiv role=\"button\" class=\"css-1t412wb\"\u003E\u003Cdiv class=\"css-hhzar2 css-1r2j9qz faqCaret2\"\u003E\u003Csvg width=\"12px\" height=\"6px\" viewBox=\"0 0 12 6\" version=\"1.1\" xmlns=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.w3.org\u002F2000\u002Fsvg\" xmlns:xlink=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.w3.org\u002F1999\u002Fxlink\"\u003E\u003Cg stroke=\"none\" stroke-width=\"1\" fill=\"none\" fill-rule=\"evenodd\"\u003E\u003Cg transform=\"translate(-566.000000, -618.000000)\" stroke=\"#979797\"\u003E\u003Cpolyline id=\"Path-2\" points=\"567 618 572.230938 623.230938 577.381644 618.080232\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fpolyline\u003E\u003C\u002Fg\u003E\u003C\u002Fg\u003E\u003C\u002Fsvg\u003E\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\u003C\u002Fbutton\u003E\u003Cdiv class=\"css-e1ipqs css-1sw9s96 faqAnswer2\"\u003E\u003Cp\u003EProbably not. The answer depends on a number of factors, including the supply in your area at the time you’re vaccinated. Check your state health department website for more information about the vaccines available in your state. \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002Finteractive\u002F2020\u002Fscience\u002Fcoronavirus-vaccine-tracker.html\"\u003EThe Pfizer and Moderna vaccines are the only two vaccines currently approved,\u003C\u002Fa\u003E although a third vaccine from Johnson & Johnson is on the way.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\u003Cdiv class=\"css-k59gj9\"\u003E\u003Cbutton type=\"button\" id=\"faq-question-3\" class=\"css-1e2usoh\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"css-1jz6h6z\"\u003EHow long will the vaccine last? Will I need another one next year?\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cdiv role=\"button\" class=\"css-1t412wb\"\u003E\u003Cdiv class=\"css-hhzar2 css-1r2j9qz faqCaret3\"\u003E\u003Csvg width=\"12px\" height=\"6px\" viewBox=\"0 0 12 6\" version=\"1.1\" xmlns=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.w3.org\u002F2000\u002Fsvg\" xmlns:xlink=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.w3.org\u002F1999\u002Fxlink\"\u003E\u003Cg stroke=\"none\" stroke-width=\"1\" fill=\"none\" fill-rule=\"evenodd\"\u003E\u003Cg transform=\"translate(-566.000000, -618.000000)\" stroke=\"#979797\"\u003E\u003Cpolyline id=\"Path-2\" points=\"567 618 572.230938 623.230938 577.381644 618.080232\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fpolyline\u003E\u003C\u002Fg\u003E\u003C\u002Fg\u003E\u003C\u002Fsvg\u003E\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\u003C\u002Fbutton\u003E\u003Cdiv class=\"css-e1ipqs css-1sw9s96 faqAnswer3\"\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThat is to be determined. It’s possible that Covid-19 vaccinations will become an annual event, just like the flu shot. \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2020\u002F11\u002F17\u002Fhealth\u002Fcoronavirus-immunity.html\"\u003EOr it may be that the benefits of the vaccine last longer than a year.\u003C\u002Fa\u003E We have to wait to see how durable the protection from the vaccines is. To determine this, researchers are going to be tracking vaccinated people to look for “breakthrough cases” — those people who get sick with Covid-19 despite vaccination. That is a sign of weakening protection and will give researchers clues about how long the vaccine lasts. They will also be monitoring levels of antibodies and T cells in the blood of vaccinated people to determine whether and when a booster shot might be needed. It’s conceivable that people may need boosters every few months, once a year or only every few years. It’s just a matter of waiting for the data.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\u003Cdiv class=\"css-k59gj9\"\u003E\u003Cbutton type=\"button\" id=\"faq-question-4\" class=\"css-1e2usoh\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"css-1jz6h6z\"\u003EWill my employer require vaccinations?\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cdiv role=\"button\" class=\"css-1t412wb\"\u003E\u003Cdiv class=\"css-hhzar2 css-1r2j9qz faqCaret4\"\u003E\u003Csvg width=\"12px\" height=\"6px\" viewBox=\"0 0 12 6\" version=\"1.1\" xmlns=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.w3.org\u002F2000\u002Fsvg\" xmlns:xlink=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.w3.org\u002F1999\u002Fxlink\"\u003E\u003Cg stroke=\"none\" stroke-width=\"1\" fill=\"none\" fill-rule=\"evenodd\"\u003E\u003Cg transform=\"translate(-566.000000, -618.000000)\" stroke=\"#979797\"\u003E\u003Cpolyline id=\"Path-2\" points=\"567 618 572.230938 623.230938 577.381644 618.080232\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fpolyline\u003E\u003C\u002Fg\u003E\u003C\u002Fg\u003E\u003C\u002Fsvg\u003E\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\u003C\u002Fbutton\u003E\u003Cdiv class=\"css-e1ipqs css-1sw9s96 faqAnswer4\"\u003E\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2020\u002F12\u002F18\u002Fus\u002Feeoc-employers-coronavirus-mandate.html\"\u003EEmployers do have the right to compel their workers to be vaccinated once a vaccine is formally approved.\u003C\u002Fa\u003E Many hospital systems, for example, require annual flu shots. But employees can seek exemptions based on medical reasons or religious beliefs. In such cases, employers are supposed to provide a “reasonable accommodation” — with a coronavirus vaccine, for example, a worker might be allowed to work if they wear a mask, or to work from home.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\u003Cdiv class=\"css-k59gj9\"\u003E\u003Cbutton type=\"button\" id=\"faq-question-5\" class=\"css-1e2usoh\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"css-1jz6h6z\"\u003EWhere can I find out more?\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cdiv role=\"button\" class=\"css-1t412wb\"\u003E\u003Cdiv class=\"css-hhzar2 css-1r2j9qz faqCaret5\"\u003E\u003Csvg xmlns:xlink=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.w3.org\u002F1999\u002Fxlink\"\u003E\u003Cg stroke=\"none\" stroke-width=\"1\" fill=\"none\" fill-rule=\"evenodd\"\u003E\u003Cg transform=\"translate(-566.000000, css-1sw9s96 faqAnswer5\"\u003E\u003Cp\u003EIf you have other questions about the coronavirus vaccine, \u003Ca F.A.Q.\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\u003Cscript\u003E\"use strict\";var
